title.value: The Machine Learning for Combinatorial Optimization Competition (ML4CO): Results and Insights
title.justification: The title explicitly states the focus of the paper on the Machine Learning for Combinatorial Optimization Competition and its results and insights.
title.quote:
The Machine Learning for Combinatorial Optimization
Competition (ML4CO): Results and Insights

extractions.description: This paper presents the outcomes and insights from the Machine Learning for Combinatorial Optimization Competition (ML4CO), which aimed to enhance combinatorial optimization solvers by integrating machine learning. The competition encompassed tasks such as finding optimal solutions, generating tight optimality certificates, and configuring solvers. It involved three main datasets: balanced item placement, workload apportionment, and maritime inventory routing. Participants used a unified interface to train their models, which were evaluated based on specific metrics across diverse instances.

type.justification: The paper reports on a competition, presenting results and insights based on empirical evaluations of various models on given tasks and datasets.
type.quote:
The competition featured three challenging tasks: finding the best feasible solution,
producing the tightest optimality certificate, and giving an appropriate solver configuration.

name.justification: The paper centers on using machine learning models to improve combinatorial optimization solvers, explicitly mentioned throughout the document.
name.quote: Combinatorial optimization is a well-established area in operations research and computer science.

name.justification: The paper discusses the application of machine learning in the context of combinatorial optimization.
name.quote:
...recent years have seen a
surge of interest in using machine learning as a new approach for solving combinatorial problems...

name.justification: SCIP is the solver mentioned in the paper that participants enhance using machine learning models for various tasks.
name.quote:
Each of them corresponds to
a specific control task arising in the open-source solver SCIP (Gamrath et al., 2020) and is exposed through a unified OpenAI Gym-like API based on the Python library Ecole (Prouvost et al., 2020).

is_contributed.justification: SCIP is used as the base solver in the competition, not a contribution of this particular paper.
is_contributed.quote:
the environment
runs a full-fledged branch-and-cut algorithm with SCIP, and the participants only control the branching decisions of the solver.

is_executed.justification: SCIP is the solver on which tasks are executed during the competition.
is_executed.quote: Execution time was limited to 15 minutes.

is_compared.justification: The paper does not focus on numerically comparing SCIP to other models; instead, it evaluates the performance of participants' models using SCIP.
is_compared.quote:
hree challenges for machine learning. Each of them corresponds to
a specific control task arising in the open-source solver SCIP

referenced_paper_title.justification: The SCIP solver is referenced by its optimization suite paper, as given in the citation.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The SCIP Optimization Suite 7.0. Technical report, Optimization Online, March 2020.

name.justification: This is one of the datasets specifically evaluated on during the competition, as part of the problem benchmarks.
name.quote: Benchmark 1: Balanced Item Placement This problem involves spreading items, e.g., files or processes, across containers...

referenced_paper_title.value: Mirplib–a library of maritime inventory routing problem instances: Survey, core model, and benchmark results.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset was inspired by real-life applications and bears reference to a previous instance library.
referenced_paper_title.quote: instances corresponding to this benchmark are assembled from a public dataset (Papageorgiou et al., 2014), whose origin was kept secret to prevent cheating.

name.justification: This is another dataset explicitly mentioned and utilized in the competition for evaluating solutions on a problem benchmark.
name.quote: Benchmark 2: Workload Apportionment This problem deals with apportioning workloads, e.g., data streams, across as few workers, e.g., servers, as possible.

referenced_paper_title.value: Mirplib–a library of maritime inventory routing problem instances: Survey, core model, and benchmark results.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The mention of data assembly aligns the usage with an existing library to benchmark results.
referenced_paper_title.quote: instances corresponding to this benchmark are assembled from a public dataset (Papageorgiou et al., 2014), whose origin was kept secret to prevent cheating.

name.justification: This is one of the datasets used in the competition, specifically as part of the challenging tasks presented.
name.quote: Benchmark 3: Maritime Inventory Routing (Anonymous Problem) This problem plays an integral role in global bulk shipping.

referenced_paper_title.value: Mirplib–a library of maritime inventory routing problem instances: Survey, core model, and benchmark results.
referenced_paper_title.justification: It specifically references a public dataset connected to a previous library for routing problems.
referenced_paper_title.quote: instances corresponding to this benchmark are assembled from a public dataset (Papageorgiou et al., 2014), whose origin was kept secret to prevent cheating.

name.justification: Ecole is mentioned as a Python library used in conjunction with SCIP, wrapped in an OpenAI Gym-like API for the competition tasks.
name.quote: exposed through a unified OpenAI Gym-like API based on the Python library Ecole (Prouvost et al., 2020).

referenced_paper_title.value: Ecole: A gym-like library for machine learning in combinatorial optimization solvers.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The library is explicitly referenced by its paper citation.
referenced_paper_title.quote:
Ecole: A gym-like library for machine learning in combinatorial optimization
solvers.
